cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
what was the name of the horse in steptoe and son
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process: In the British sitcom "Steptoe and Son," the characters Albert Steptoe and his son Harold Steptoe are often seen with a horse that plays a significant role in their lives as rag-and-bone men. The horse's name is a notable aspect of the show. After recalling the series and its characters, I remember that the horse is named "Bert." 

Answer: Bert

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
what was the name of the horse in steptoe and son
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['Steptoe and Son\n', 'The series\' title music, "Old Ned", won its composer Ron Grainer his second successive Ivor Novello award. The series had no standard set of opening titles but the opening sequences would often feature the Steptoe\'s horse, Hercules. "Steptoe and Son" is the Steptoes\' trading name, but as established in the first episode, the "Son" is not Harold as initially believed, but Albert. The name dates from when he and his mother—Mrs. Steptoe—worked the rounds. The first series has the pair as very rough looking and often dirty and wearing ragged clothes, but they quickly "tidied up" for later series.\n', 'Steptoe and Son is a 1972 British comedy drama film and a spin-off from the popular British television comedy series of the same name about father-and-son rag-and-bone dealers. It starred Wilfrid Brambell and Harry H. Corbett as the eponymous characters, Albert and Harold Steptoe respectively. It also features Carolyn Seymour. A sequel, "Steptoe and Son Ride Again", was released the following year.\n', 'Albert Steptoe, as the father in Steptoe and Son referred to relatives from "Stoke-on-Trent".\n', 'Steptoe and Son Ride Again\n', 'Steptoe and Son is a British sitcom created by comedy writers Ray Galton and Alan Simpson, originally broadcast over four series between 1962 and 1965, and again for a further three series and two Christmas specials between 1970 and 1974. Two films followed the series; "Steptoe and Son" and "Steptoe and Son Ride Again".\n', 'BULLET::::- "Steptoe and Son"\n', 'BULLET::::- "Steptoe and Son"\n', 'BULLET::::- "Steptoe and Son"\n', 'BULLET::::- "Steptoe and Son"\n']

question_info.question: what was the name of the horse in steptoe and son
passages:
Steptoe and Son
The series' title music, "Old Ned", won its composer Ron Grainer his second successive Ivor Novello award. The series had no standard set of opening titles but the opening sequences would often feature the Steptoe's horse, Hercules. "Steptoe and Son" is the Steptoes' trading name, but as established in the first episode, the "Son" is not Harold as initially believed, but Albert. The name dates from when he and his mother—Mrs. Steptoe—worked the rounds. The first series has the pair as very rough looking and often dirty and wearing ragged clothes, but they quickly "tidied up" for later series.
Steptoe and Son is a 1972 British comedy drama film and a spin-off from the popular British television comedy series of the same name about father-and-son rag-and-bone dealers. It starred Wilfrid Brambell and Harry H. Corbett as the eponymous characters, Albert and Harold Steptoe respectively. It also features Carolyn Seymour. A sequel, "Steptoe and Son Ride Again", was released the following year.
Albert Steptoe, as the father in Steptoe and Son referred to relatives from "Stoke-on-Trent".
Steptoe and Son Ride Again
Steptoe and Son is a British sitcom created by comedy writers Ray Galton and Alan Simpson, originally broadcast over four series between 1962 and 1965, and again for a further three series and two Christmas specials between 1970 and 1974. Two films followed the series; "Steptoe and Son" and "Steptoe and Son Ride Again".
